results: This movie is a prime example of Hollywood ego, just like the new king kong movie. Superman is the ultimate superhero and should be respected, even in tights. Brandon Routh's performance as Superman was the worst I've ever seen. From the beginning, I wanted to feed him a piece of kryptonite. He just looked ridiculous in the costume. But let's not forget about Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane. She was a terrible choice. Lois Lane is supposed to be a tough reporter, but she came across more like a schoolgirl in this movie. The plot was weak and predictable. Who would have guessed that Superman actually has a son? The acting was atrocious. The only saving grace was Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor. He was brilliant, but even he couldn't salvage this film. They should have cast the actors from 'Lois and Clark' and come up with a different story. I watched this movie right after 'The Hills Have Eyes' and I was shocked to discover that there are even worse movies out there.

Superman is the original super hero and deserves to be treated with respect even though he wears tights. Brandon Routh was the worst superman I've ever seen, from the start of the movie u just wanna shove a chunk of kryptonite down his throat. He looks just silly wearing the costume. But enough about him, Kate Bosworth was a bad choise for lois lane, she is supposed to be a hard ass reporter, but in this movie she looks more like a schoolgirl. The plot was weak and predictable (WOW, He is actually supermans son, who would have ever thought....) and the acting was horrible. This movie has one good thing going for it, and it's name is Kevin Spacey. His portrayal of Lex Luthor was brilliant but even he could not save this movie. What this movie needed was the cast of 'lois and clark' (except Kevin Spacey of course) and a different story. I watched this movie after watching 'the hills have eyes' and I was chocked to learn that there existed worse movies then that.

results:
A couple of years ago, I left a comment on the IMDB page for 'The Real McCoys' TV series. I expressed then and reiterate now that it was an endearing, humorous, and enjoyable show, with exceptional performances and captivating characters.

Recently, I had the opportunity to watch four old episodes on DVD, along with the 2000 Reunion featuring Richard Crenna, Kathy Nolan, and Tony Martinez. As another reviewer mentioned, it's strange that Lydia Reed (Hassie) and Michael Winkelman (Little Luke) were not mentioned, but perhaps their whereabouts can be discovered through SAG or AFTRA.

The reunion special was well-executed and provided us with many fascinating insights into the series. However, one piece of behind-the-scenes information that remained undisclosed was whether or not Kathy Nolan regretted her decision to leave the show due to a contentious contract dispute. This unfortunate departure left Luke as a 'widower' in its final season, which was quite disappointing. Nolan went on to star in a less successful comedy named 'Broadside', which revolved around female nurses in the Pacific during World War II. The title, 'Broadside', was supposed to be humorous, but it fell flat.

Unlike the current TV landscape, which is filled with vulgar, scandalous, and violent content that undermines our values, 'The Real McCoys' provided entertainment with its wholesome values and remarkable characters. I express my gratitude to everyone involved, including the creator, Irving Pinkus, for bringing this show into my family's life. We never missed an episode.
prompts:

As another writer here mentioned, it is curious that Lydia Reed (Hassie) and Michael Winkelman (Little Luke) weren't refered to, but perhaps they can be tracked down via SAG or AFTRA.

The reunion show was well done and gave us many unknown insights into the show. One piece of inside information we did NOT get was whether or not Kathy Nolan regretted quitting the show in an unpleasant contract dispute, which left Luke a 'widow' in it's last year, which wasn't very good. Nolan went on to do a bomb of a comedy called 'Broadside', about women nurses in the Pacific in WW II. Get it? BROADside? No, not funny.

Unlike the sleazy, salacious, and violent TRASH on TV now that is so undermining our values, 'The Real McCoys' entertained with decent values and fine human beings. And I thank all involved, including the creator, Irving Pinkus, for having brought it to my family. We never missed it. Text:

prediction:
A couple of years ago, I left a comment on the IMDB page for 'The Real McCoys' TV series. I expressed then and reiterate now that it was an endearing, humorous, and enjoyable show, with exceptional performances and captivating characters.

Recently, I had the opportunity to watch four old episodes on DVD, along with the 2000 Reunion featuring Richard Crenna, Kathy Nolan, and Tony Martinez. As another reviewer mentioned, it's strange that Lydia Reed (Hassie) and Michael Winkelman (Little Luke) were not mentioned, but perhaps their whereabouts can be discovered through SAG or AFTRA.

The reunion special was well-executed and provided us with many fascinating insights into the series. However, one piece of behind-the-scenes information that remained undisclosed was whether or not Kathy Nolan regretted her decision to leave the show due to a contentious contract dispute. This unfortunate departure left Luke as a 'widower' in its final season, which was quite disappointing. Nolan went on to star in a less successful comedy named 'Broadside', which revolved around female nurses in the Pacific during World War II. The title, 'Broadside', was supposed to be humorous, but it fell flat.

Unlike the current TV landscape, which is filled with vulgar, scandalous, and violent content that undermines our values, 'The Real McCoys' provided entertainment with its wholesome values and remarkable characters. I express my gratitude to everyone involved, including the creator, Irving Pinkus, for bringing this show into my family's life. We never missed an episode.

results: I have to say, this is a prime example of Hollywood arrogance, only surpassed by the latest Godzilla film. Superman is the original superhero and should be treated with reverence, even if he does wear tights. Brandon Routh was the most disappointing Superman I've ever witnessed; I wanted nothing more than to stuff a piece of kryptonite down his throat from the beginning of the movie. He just looked ridiculous in the costume. But let's not dwell on him too much. Kate Bosworth was a poor choice for Lois Lane; she's meant to be a tough-as-nails reporter, but in this film, she comes across as more of a schoolgirl. The plot was feeble and predictable (surprise, he's actually Superman's son - who could have seen that coming?), and the acting was abysmal. The only redeeming quality of this film is Kevin Spacey. His portrayal of Lex Luthor was outstanding, but even he couldn't salvage this disaster. What this movie needed was the cast of "Lois and Clark" (minus Kevin Spacey, of course) and a different storyline. I watched this film right after seeing "The Hills Have Eyes," and I was flabbergasted to discover that there were actually worse movies out there.
